SEC. 101. Extension of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through March 31, 2004. Activities authorized by part A of title IV of the Social Security Act, and by sections 510, 1108(b), and 1925, shall continue through March 31, 2004, with necessary appropriations from the Treasury. Grants and payments for these activities in the first two quarters of fiscal year 2004 will be at the level of fiscal year 2002. Amendments are made for supplemental grants in certain states. Amendments are made to various sections of the Social Security Act, including changes to grant funding timelines and maintenance of effort requirements. These changes extend activities authorized under part A of title IV through March 31, 2004, with funding levels set at fiscal year 2002 levels for the first two quarters of fiscal year 2004. SEC. 102 extends the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority through March 31, 2004, with funding levels maintained at fiscal year 2002 levels for the first two quarters of fiscal year 2004. SEC. 201 allows disclosure of return information for income contingent repayment of student loans. TITLE II--TAX PROVISIONS

SEC. 201. Disclosure of return information for income contingent repayment of student loans amended to extend deadline to December 31, 2004.

SEC. 202. Extension of Internal Revenue Service user fees with the addition of a new section 7528. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees on requests to the IRS for ruling, opinion, and determination letters, with fees varying based on categories and payable in advance. Exemptions and reduced fees will be provided as determined appropriate by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide exemptions and reduced fees under a program for requests regarding pension plans, with no user fees for determination letters on qualified status of plans by eligible employers. During the fifth plan year of a pension benefit plan's existence, or at the end of any remedial amendment period within the first 5 plan years. The text discusses definitions and rules related to pension benefit plans, eligible employers, and highly compensated employees. Eligible employers must have at least one non-highly compensated employee participating in the plan. The determination of whether an employer is eligible under subparagraph (B) is based on the date of the request. Any request under subparagraph (B) is not considered for determining average fees charged. The average fee charged under the program must meet a minimum amount as specified in the table. The IRS imposes various fees for exempt organization rulings, employee plan determinations, chief counsel rulings, and more. No fee is imposed for requests made after December 31, 2004. The Revenue Act of 1987 and the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 are repealed. Fees collected under the Internal Revenue Code must be approved by an appropriations Act. The amendments apply to requests made after the enactment of this Act. COBRA fees are extended to March 31, 2004. Medicare cost-sharing provisions are addressed in Title IV. Title IV of the Act addresses Medicare cost-sharing provisions, including the extension of Medicare cost-sharing for certain qualifying individuals. Extension of Sunset for Medicare Cost-Sharing: Section 1902(a)(10)(E)(iv) of the Social Security Act is amended to extend the sunset provision to March 2004. Additionally, the total amount available for allocation under Section 1933(c) is adjusted for fiscal years 2002 and 2003. Section 1933 of the Social Security Act is amended to include a special rule for the first quarter of 2004, with a total allocation amount of $100,000,000. SEC. 402 extends the provision equalizing urban and rural standardized Medicare inpatient hospital payments. The amendment in the Miscellaneous Appropriations Act, 2003 changes the deadline from September 30, 2003, to March 31, 2004. The effective date of the amendment is subject to the Secretary of Health and Human Services' determination of administrative feasibility. The Secretary may delay implementing amendments to comply with Congressional intent, no later than November 1, 2003. If implementation is delayed, adjustments will be made for fiscal year 2004 to ensure total payments for inpatient hospital services remain the same. The Secretary has the authority to delay implementing amendments to comply with Congressional intent until November 1, 2003. Any adjustments made for fiscal year 2004 will ensure that total payments for inpatient hospital services remain the same. The application of certain subparagraphs will not affect payment rates for services furnished after September 30, 2004, and the Secretary is not required to prescribe regulations or provide notice in the Federal Register for carrying out such authority. The Secretary has the authority to delay implementing amendments until November 1, 2003, with no administrative or judicial review allowed for any delays or determinations made.
